prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: 24 is the best television show!!!!! It's an incredible TV series with an incredible suspense, excellent plots and unforgettable characters. And the first episode of all is my best evidence. Because it's only the first episode, only the introduction, and you are hooked because of the plot and the continuous twists and turns.

Jack Bauer is a federal agent who is assigned the protection of the senator David Palmer. He can't trust in anybody because people of the CTU may be involved. And, when this events occurred his daughter: Kimberly escapes from house to a party. But...

At the end of the episode, you want to watch more, and more, and more.

It's only the first of the lot, and it's excellent. Label: pos Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text:
I have seen 5 episodes of The Office, and I have no idea why I continue except maybe waiting for it to get better.

To me this show is just riding on its reputation, with no real originality. As we sat around watching these episodes, we all speculated on what was going to happen.

The episode of the boss with a terrible sense of humor was actually a big, yea right, for us. He's inappropriate in the workplace and acts clueless, and truth be told, he needed to be fired.

I consider myself a pretty good critic, taking in everything, but I must say, The Office is comparable to the old show, Gilligan's Island. I give it a 2, only because they deserve 1 better than a 1 because they actually have talented actors.

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos.

Each label is described as follows:
negative: A negative movie review.
positive: A positive movie review.

Text: While I recently gave OPERATION PETTICOAT a positive review, I really didn't like this film even though it had so many similarities. Both were made just a few years apart, both starred Cary Grant and both were WWII comedies. However, the overall tone and style of the films were quite different. KISS HER FOR ME, overall, just seemed like a cheaper film--with poor writing, little energy and some VERY broad performances--even when compared to OPERATION PETTICOAT. I think that at least much of the blame for this lies in casting Jayne Mansfield. The combination of her ample talents and limited acting ability really made this A-budget film look like it came from a 3rd rate studio. Plus, there wasn't much chemistry or energy in pairing her with Cary Grant--an actor generally loved for his grace and class. It's sort of like pairing Sir Lawrence Olivier with Marjorie Main.
Label: neg

Text: {text}
Label:

invocation_context.text:
24 is the most amazing television series ever! It's filled with incredible suspense, mind-blowing plots, and unforgettable characters. And let me tell you, the first episode is pure gold. From the very beginning, you're completely hooked by the captivating storyline and the never-ending twists and turns.

Meet Jack Bauer, a federal agent tasked with protecting Senator David Palmer. But here's the catch, he can't trust anyone at the CTU as they might be involved in some shady business. And just when things couldn't get any worse, his daughter Kimberly decides to escape from home and attend a party. Talk about a rollercoaster of events!

By the end of the episode, you're left craving for more. You just can't get enough! And guess what? This is just the tip of the iceberg. There are countless episodes waiting to blow your mind.

Trust me, this is just the beginning, and it's absolutely phenomenal.

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: Gary Busey is the title character, Frank "Bulletproof" McBain, your standard-issue reckless maverick cop who's earned his nickname because no matter how many bullets he takes (38 and counting), he never stops going after the bad guys.

When a cutting-edge U.S. tank dubbed "Thunderblast" is driven across the border into Mexico, it's nabbed by revolutionaries / terrorists led by General Brogado (Rene Enriquez) and Libyan Colonel Kartiff (Henry Silva), who's aligned himself with Russian villains. The Army personnel involved are kept as prisoners, chief among them Devon Shepard (Darlanne Fluegel), who happens to be McBain's ex-girlfriend. McBain is then recruited by the Army for a rescue mission.

Busey may not have the physical presence of say, someone like Schwarzenegger, who would have been another appropriate lead for a film of this type, but he's a blast as a self- confident dude who's quick with the wisecracks. Fluegel is a great female lead; she not only looks incredibly sexy but makes for a fine butt-kicking action babe. Enriquez, Silva, Juan Fernandez, and the always welcome William Smith (as a Russian major) are loathsome scum in the classic action movie tradition. The supporting cast is quite full of familiar and reliable character actors: L.Q. Jones, R.G. Armstrong, Thalmus Rasulala, Lincoln Kilpatrick, Mills Watson, Luke Askew, Danny Trejo, and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa.

T.L. Lankford and B.J. Goldman supply the script, based on a story by Lankford and veteran B director Fred Olen Ray. It's the kind of script where you just know the writers have their tongues in their cheeks: they know their material is absurd and cheesy, and just have fun throwing credibility out the window. Veteran action director Steve Carver keeps it moving and delivers a respectable amount of gunfire, explosions, and general all-out mayhem.

"Bulletproof" is good fun for the action fan who doesn't mind switching off their brain now and then and just enjoying a generous assortment of violence and humor.

7/10 Label: pos Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text:
Mel Gibson stars as the fearless and relentless Detective Max Rockatansky, known as 'Mad Max', in this post-apocalyptic action thriller. Despite being constantly outnumbered and outgunned, Max never backs down from a fight and continues to pursue justice in a lawless wasteland.

When a ruthless gang of motorcycle-riding criminals led by the sadistic Toecutter (Hugh Keays-Byrne) terrorizes the town, Max is determined to bring them to justice. Along the way, he forms an unlikely alliance with a skilled mechanic named The Gyro Captain (Bruce Spence) and a group of freedom fighters who are seeking revenge against the gang.

Gibson's intense and gritty performance as Max is complemented by the stunning presence of Joanne Samuel as Jessie, Max's wife, who adds depth and emotion to the film. Keays-Byrne delivers a chilling portrayal of Toecutter, making him a memorable and menacing villain. The supporting cast, including Steve Bisley, Tim Burns, and Roger Ward, add to the film's authenticity and intensity.

The screenplay, written by James McCausland and director George Miller, is a masterful blend of adrenaline-fueled action and thought-provoking themes. Miller's direction is superb, capturing the desolate and chaotic world of the future with stunning visuals and exhilarating chase sequences.

'Mad Max' is an adrenaline-pumping thrill ride that will leave audiences on the edge of their seats. With its intense action, compelling characters, and breathtaking cinematography, it is a must-see for fans of the genre.

8/10

invocation_context.text:
I have seen 4 episodes of Caveman, and I still can't figure out why I'm watching it. Maybe I'm hoping it will improve.

This show seems to rely solely on its advertisements, lacking any real humor. As my friends and I watched these episodes, we couldn't help but speculate about what would happen next.

The episode with the cave-woman with an attitude was a complete joke. She's vulgar in public and acts tough with strangers, and honestly, she deserved to be put in her place.

I like to think of myself as a fair critic, considering all aspects, but I have to say, Cavemen is on par with the old show, My Mother, the Car. I'll give it a 3, only because it's slightly better than a 2, and someone actually invested money in it.

invocation_context.text:
Billy Bob Thornton stars as the main character, Jack 'Steelheart' Mason, a fearless renegade cop who never backs down from a fight, no matter how many punches he takes (countless and counting).

When a state-of-the-art helicopter known as 'SkyBlazer' is stolen and flown into enemy territory, it falls into the hands of a group of mercenaries led by General Vargas (Carlos Gomez) and his ruthless sidekick, Colonel Vasquez (Miguel Sandoval), who have joined forces with a band of international criminals. The military personnel on board are taken hostage, including Mason's estranged sister, Sarah (Michelle Rodriguez). Mason is then recruited by a top-secret government agency to embark on a daring rescue mission.

Thornton may not have the physical prowess of a Stallone or a Van Damme, who would have been fitting choices for a film like this, but he brings a charismatic energy to his role as a cocky and quick-witted hero. Rodriguez is a captivating female lead, exuding both beauty and strength as she kicks some serious butt. Gomez, Sandoval, John Ortiz, and the always reliable Danny Trejo (as a notorious arms dealer) portray despicable villains in classic action movie fashion. The supporting cast is filled with familiar faces, including Keith David, Tom Berenger, Clifton Collins Jr., and Michael Rooker.

The screenplay, penned by E.M. Davidson and S.R. Thompson, based on a story by Davidson and seasoned action director John McTiernan, is a tongue-in-cheek homage to the genre. The writers fully embrace the absurdity and cheesiness of the material, delivering a script that doesn't take itself too seriously. McTiernan's direction keeps the pace brisk and ensures a satisfying amount of gunfights, explosions, and overall chaos.

'Steelheart' is a thrilling ride for action enthusiasts who are willing to suspend disbelief and simply enjoy a thrilling blend of violence and humor.

8/10

invocation_context.text: Gary Busey stars as the fearless and relentless cop, Frank 'Bulletproof' McBain, known for his ability to withstand countless bullets without ever giving up on his mission to take down the bad guys. When a state-of-the-art U.S. tank called 'Thunderblast' falls into the hands of revolutionaries and terrorists led by General Brogado and Libyan Colonel Kartiff, McBain is recruited by the Army to embark on a high-stakes rescue mission. Alongside McBain is his ex-girlfriend Devon Shepard, played by the stunning and action-packed Darlanne Fluegel. The film also features a despicable cast of villains, including Enriquez, Silva, Fernandez, and Smith. With a talented supporting cast of familiar and reliable character actors, a clever script by T.L. Lankford and B.J. Goldman, and expert direction by Steve Carver, 'Bulletproof' is a thrilling and entertaining action film that blends humor and explosive action. It may not have the physical presence of a Schwarzenegger, but Busey delivers a blast as the self-assured and quick-witted McBain. Fluegel adds to the excitement as a sexy and kick-ass female lead. The film's absurd and cheesy nature is embraced by the writers, resulting in a fun and enjoyable experience for action fans who are willing to suspend disbelief and indulge in a satisfying dose of violence and humor. Overall, 'Bulletproof' earns a solid 7 out of 10.

invocation_context.text: Although I recently praised OPERATION PETTICOAT, I must admit that I did not enjoy this film as much, despite its many similarities. Both movies were released within a few years of each other, featured Cary Grant as the lead, and were set during World War II. However, the overall vibe and execution of these films differed significantly. KISS HER FOR ME, in comparison, felt like a lower-budget production, with subpar writing, lackluster performances, and a noticeable lack of energy. It paled in comparison to the quality of OPERATION PETTICOAT. I believe a significant portion of the blame lies with the casting of Jayne Mansfield. Her talents, though abundant, were unable to compensate for her limited acting abilities, resulting in the film feeling like it belonged to a less esteemed studio. Furthermore, the chemistry and energy between her and Cary Grant were sorely lacking, as Grant is typically revered for his elegance and sophistication. It was akin to pairing Sir Lawrence Olivier with Marjorie Main, an odd and mismatched combination.

Each label is described as follows:
negative: A negative movie review.
positive: A positive movie review.

Text: While I recently gave OPERATION PETTICOAT a positive review, I really didn't like this film even though it had so many similarities. Both were made just a few years apart, both starred Cary Grant and both were WWII comedies. However, the overall tone and style of the films were quite different. KISS HER FOR ME, overall, just seemed like a cheaper film--with poor writing, little energy and some VERY broad performances--even when compared to OPERATION PETTICOAT. I think that at least much of the blame for this lies in casting Jayne Mansfield. The combination of her ample talents and limited acting ability really made this A-budget film look like it came from a 3rd rate studio. Plus, there wasn't much chemistry or energy in pairing her with Cary Grant--an actor generally loved for his grace and class. It's sort of like pairing Sir Lawrence Olivier with Marjorie Main.
Label: neg

prompt:
Given the following classification examples, annotate the unlabeled example with a prediction that must correspond to exactly one of the following labels: neg, pos. Each label is described as follows: negative: A negative movie review. positive: A positive movie review. Text: Gary Busey is the title character, Frank "Bulletproof" McBain, your standard-issue reckless maverick cop who's earned his nickname because no matter how many bullets he takes (38 and counting), he never stops going after the bad guys.

When a cutting-edge U.S. tank dubbed "Thunderblast" is driven across the border into Mexico, it's nabbed by revolutionaries / terrorists led by General Brogado (Rene Enriquez) and Libyan Colonel Kartiff (Henry Silva), who's aligned himself with Russian villains. The Army personnel involved are kept as prisoners, chief among them Devon Shepard (Darlanne Fluegel), who happens to be McBain's ex-girlfriend. McBain is then recruited by the Army for a rescue mission.

Busey may not have the physical presence of say, someone like Schwarzenegger, who would have been another appropriate lead for a film of this type, but he's a blast as a self- confident dude who's quick with the wisecracks. Fluegel is a great female lead; she not only looks incredibly sexy but makes for a fine butt-kicking action babe. Enriquez, Silva, Juan Fernandez, and the always welcome William Smith (as a Russian major) are loathsome scum in the classic action movie tradition. The supporting cast is quite full of familiar and reliable character actors: L.Q. Jones, R.G. Armstrong, Thalmus Rasulala, Lincoln Kilpatrick, Mills Watson, Luke Askew, Danny Trejo, and Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa.

T.L. Lankford and B.J. Goldman supply the script, based on a story by Lankford and veteran B director Fred Olen Ray. It's the kind of script where you just know the writers have their tongues in their cheeks: they know their material is absurd and cheesy, and just have fun throwing credibility out the window. Veteran action director Steve Carver keeps it moving and delivers a respectable amount of gunfire, explosions, and general all-out mayhem.

"Bulletproof" is good fun for the action fan who doesn't mind switching off their brain now and then and just enjoying a generous assortment of violence and humor.

7/10 Label: pos Text: {text} Label:

invocation_context.text: Even though OPERATION PETTICOAT received a positive review from me recently, I was quite disappointed with this film even though it had numerous similarities. Both movies were produced within a few years of each other, both featured Cary Grant as the lead, and both were set during World War II with a comedic twist. However, the overall vibe and style of the films were strikingly different. KISS HER FOR ME, on the whole, felt like a much cheaper production with subpar writing, a lack of enthusiasm, and some extremely exaggerated performances, especially when compared to OPERATION PETTICOAT. I believe a significant part of the blame for this lies in the casting of Jayne Mansfield. Her considerable attributes coupled with her limited acting abilities made this high-budget film appear as though it came from a low-quality studio. Additionally, there was a noticeable lack of chemistry and energy between her and Cary Grant, an actor renowned for his elegance and sophistication. It's almost like pairing Sir Lawrence Olivier with Marjorie Main.

Text: I have watched 3 episodes of Caveman, and I have no idea why I continue except maybe waiting for it to get better.

To me this show is just pumping itself off the commercials, with no real humor. As we sat around watching these shows, we all speculated on what was going to happen.

The episode of the woman cave-woman with a attitude was actually a big, yea right, for us. she's crude in a theater and acts tough to strangers, and truth be told, she needed a slap

I consider myself a pretty good reviewer, taking in everything, but I must say, Cavemen is comparable to the old show, My mother, the car. I give it a 2, only because they deserve 1 better than a 1 because they actually spent money on it. Label: neg Text: {text} Label:

However, the overall feel and execution of the two movies were quite different. I believe that a big part of the disappointment stems from the casting of Jayne Mansfield. Her ample talents combined with her limited acting ability made this supposedly high-quality film appear as if it was produced by a low-tier studio. Furthermore, the chemistry and energy between her and Cary Grant were lacking, which is a shame considering Grant's usual reputation for his elegance and sophistication. It's almost as if they paired a distinguished actor like Sir Lawrence Olivier with someone like Marjorie Main.

invocation_context.text:
Gary Busey stars as the fearless cop Frank 'Bulletproof' McBain, a character known for his unwavering determination to take down criminals no matter how many bullets he's taken. In this action-packed film, a high-tech tank called 'Thunderblast' is stolen by revolutionaries and terrorists led by General Brogado and Colonel Kartiff. McBain's ex-girlfriend, Devon Shepard, is among the Army prisoners taken captive. McBain is recruited by the Army to rescue them.

While Busey may not have the same physical presence as Schwarzenegger, he brings an undeniable charisma to the role of McBain. Darlanne Fluegel shines as the strong and sexy female lead, and the rest of the cast, including Rene Enriquez, Henry Silva, and William Smith, portray despicable villains in true action movie fashion. The supporting cast is filled with talented character actors who bring depth to their roles.

The script, written by T.L. Lankford and B.J. Goldman, with a story by Lankford and Fred Olen Ray, embraces the absurdity and cheesiness of the genre. Director Steve Carver keeps the film fast-paced and action-packed, delivering plenty of gunfire, explosions, and chaos.

For action fans who are willing to suspend disbelief and enjoy a mix of violence and humor, 'Bulletproof' is a highly entertaining film. It may not be a masterpiece, but it delivers on its promise of fun and excitement.

Rating: 7/10
